title: Humans
description: Make products for them & not just for yourself. Focus on humans as communities, not just individuals.

sections.title: Personas
questions: Who are you building for?
Why should they care?

sections.title: Web3 services usage
questions: What kind of web3 services this human uses?
What are the data breaches in those services?

sections.title: Privacy
questions: How aware is a person of the necessity for privacy protection?
How easily person would give up privacy in exchange for services or product features?
Why this human needs privacy protection?
What would happen with a human without additional privacy?

sections.title: Personal data literacy
questions: Does a person know how his/her/theirs data has been abused?
Does a person know how to protect himself/herself/themselves?
What kind of privacy-enhancing solutions does a person use?

title: Data
description: Think of both on-chain & off-chain data when you are doing research.

sections.title: Aim
questions: What kind of data are you protecting?
Why does this data matter?

title: Challenge
description: Think of the ZK market that solves the challenge of preserving sensitive data while validating parts from KYC to age verification.

sections.title: List
questions: What are the main barriers on your way?
How do they compromise the person, you, industry?

title: Threat Actors
description: Actors could be both web2 or web3 native.

sections.title: List
questions: Who is threatening privacy-balance?
How do these bad actors use personal data?

title: Privacy Layers
description: Think of a privacy implication complexity: KYC+AML could be great for accountability in the USA, but it means the death penalty in Iran.

sections.title: Approach
questions: What privacy layer are you contributing to?
What's a trade-off compared to other layers?

title: Solution
description: Lots of Web3 solutions complement each other - an ecosystem-centric approach simplifies ideation/development.

sections.title: Brainstorm
questions: How your idea empower humans?
How sustainable is your solution in 1-3-5 years?

title: Partners
description: Partners should unlock value for you. Imagine a time when your solution has been implemented on a broader scale.

sections.title: Activation
questions: What partners could scale your idea?
What kind of value do these partners add?
What kind of partners do you need to make this happen?

title: Resources
description: Resource management could come in handy, helping to understand feasibility of idea for yourself & wider audiences (from hackathon jury to investors).

sections.title: Launch
questions: What resources do you need for a start?
What resources do you need to sustain your idea (1-3 years)?

title: Success Metrics
description: Always separate product performance metrics from the financial side.

sections.title: Product
questions: How would you measure success?
What is the one ultimate metric to track?
What would they be for humans, partners or hackathon, organizers?
How metrics would change from MVP to ultimate Product-Market-Fit?
